meanings.definition: Resembling or characteristic of a mob.
meanings.sent1: The mobby behavior of the fans at the concert showed their excitement.
meanings.sent2: The protest turned mobby as more people joined in shouting slogans.
meanings.sent3: The mobby crowd rushed towards the stage to catch a glimpse of the famous singer.
meanings.sent4: The atmosphere in the stadium was mobby, with everyone cheering loudly.
meanings.sent5: The mobby scene outside the store on Black Friday was chaotic and crowded.

meanings.sent1: The speaker's mobby speech riled up the audience, causing them to gather around.
meanings.sent2: The politician's controversial statements had a mobby effect on the crowd.
meanings.sent3: The mobby behavior of the students during the rally surprised the teachers.
meanings.sent4: The mobby nature of the situation made it difficult to control the growing crowd.
meanings.sent5: The mobby response to the announcement led to a large group forming quickly.

meanings.definition: A group of people, especially a disorderly or unruly one.
meanings.sent1: The mobby outside the stadium was loud and rowdy, eager to get inside.
meanings.sent2: The market was bustling with a mobby of shoppers looking for bargains.
meanings.sent3: The children formed a mobby in the playground, playing games together.
meanings.sent4: The mobby of fans outside the actor's hotel hoped for a glimpse of their favorite star.
meanings.sent5: The mobby at the protest grew larger as more people joined in the demonstration.
